quiz.title: AP Physics 2
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2, Quiz 7: Gas Laws, Density & The First Law
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: First Law of Thermodynamics, Ideal Gas Law, Gas density, Volume change factors, Internal energy, Work and Heat exchange

questions.question: A gas with a fixed number of molecules has 40 J of work done on it, and 25 J of heat are transferred from the gas to the surroundings. What happens to the internal energy of the gas?
questions.explanation: Using the First Law of Thermodynamics $\Delta U = Q + W$ (where $W$ is work done ON the gas). Here, $W = +40$ J and $Q = -25$ J (heat leaving). $\Delta U = -25 + 40 = +15$ J.

questions.question: A balloon is filled with nitrogen at a temperature of 273 K to a pressure of 1 atm. If the temperature is increased to 546 K and the pressure is increased to 3 atm, by what factor does the density of the nitrogen increase?
questions.explanation: Density $\rho = PM/RT$. Therefore, $\rho \propto P/T$. The ratio of new density to old density is $(P_2/P_1) \times (T_1/T_2) = (3/1) \times (273/546) = 3 \times 0.5 = 1.5$.

questions.question: By what factor does the volume of an ideal gas change if its temperature increases by 50% and pressure quadruples?
questions.explanation: From $PV = nRT$, we have $V \propto T/P$. If $T$ becomes $1.5T$ and $P$ becomes $4P$, the new volume $V' \propto (1.5T)/(4P) = 0.375(T/P)$. The factor is 0.375.

questions.question: An ideal gas is held in a container with a moveable piston. If the gas expands at a constant temperature, which of the following must be true?
options: The internal energy of the gas increases.
The gas does positive work and absorbs heat.
The gas does negative work and releases heat.
The pressure of the gas increases.
questions.explanation: In an isothermal expansion, $\Delta U = 0$. Since the gas expands, it does positive work ($W_{by} > 0$). To keep $\Delta U = 0$, the gas must absorb an equal amount of heat ($Q = W_{by}$).

questions.question: Which of the following describes a process in which no heat is exchanged with the surroundings?
questions.explanation: An adiabatic process is defined as one in which $Q = 0$. This usually happens when a system is well-insulated or the process occurs so quickly that heat has no time to flow.

questions.question: If the volume of an ideal gas is doubled while the temperature is held constant, what happens to the root-mean-square (rms) speed of the gas molecules?
questions.explanation: The rms speed $v_{rms} = \sqrt{3RT/M}$ depends only on the temperature and the molar mass of the gas. If the temperature is constant, the rms speed does not change.

questions.question: A sample of gas undergoes an isochoric process where its pressure triples. What happens to the absolute temperature of the gas?
options: It decreases by a factor of 3.
It increases by a factor of 3.
It increases by a factor of 9.
questions.explanation: In an isochoric (constant volume) process, $P/T = \text{constant}$ (Gay-Lussac's Law). If pressure triples, the absolute temperature must also triple.

questions.question: During a compression process, 100 J of work is done on a gas, and its internal energy increases by 150 J. How much heat was exchanged?
questions.explanation: Using $\Delta U = Q + W_{on}$: $150 = Q + 100 \implies Q = +50$ J. A positive $Q$ means heat was absorbed by the gas.

questions.question: A cylinder with a piston contains an ideal gas. If the piston is pushed down rapidly (adiabatically), what happens to the temperature of the gas?
options: It increases because work is done on the gas.
It decreases because the gas is compressed.
It stays the same because no heat is exchanged.
It decreases because the pressure increases.
questions.explanation: In an adiabatic compression, $Q = 0$ and $W_{on}$ is positive. $\Delta U = W_{on}$, so internal energy increases. For an ideal gas, an increase in $\Delta U$ results in an increase in temperature.

questions.question: An ideal gas is at temperature $T$. If the average kinetic energy of the molecules is doubled, what is the new temperature?
questions.explanation: The average kinetic energy $K_{avg}$ is directly proportional to the absolute temperature ($K_{avg} = 1.5 k_B T$). If $K_{avg}$ doubles, $T$ must double.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent mastery of the First Law and Gas Law ratios!
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Review the relationships between pressure, temperature, and density.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on the signs of Q and W in the First Law.
scoreMessages.0: Review the basics of the Ideal Gas Law and thermal processes.
